I was really looking forward to viewing, Alone Yet Not Alone. I don't like to criticize small indy films done on a low budget, because I know that a lot of work goes into them. At the same time, I must be honest about my personal feelings of a movie, and I was highly disappointed. The character development, the story, and the acting was quite below average performance. When I find myself wishing a film was over, I don't consider it time and money well spent. The characters did not interest me, and the story came across more like a documentary, than the epic tale it could have been.

Having said that, I really really enjoyed the musical score by Joni Eareckson Tada. As a matter of fact, I actually included it in my kids bedtime music playlist. I remember the complaints about the song not being awarded when the movie was released. A lot of people were crying wolf, and although the song is absolutely beautiful, the movie was not. This was probably the reason why it did not get the award.

A just okay supposedly true-life story with a less than true-to-life ending. Not really much in this tale that shows how the protagonist's faith in Jesus Christ got her through her trials. The truth is, many if not most, white children captured by American Indians that survived the ordeal assimilated into their respective tribes and did not want to go back to so-called white civilization (Read the story of Cynthia Ann Parker for one). Also, the story of life for a female within an American Indian tribe is also highly romanticized. Women within tribes lived brutal existences, even if they were native to the tribe, where they did nearly all of the arduous work and the men primarily hunted and made war. Even the settler's lives themselves were highly romanticized by portraying life as relatively easy when the opposite was true. This movie is filled with cliches from much better films and borrows heavily from the 1992 feature, The Last of the Mohicans, with Daniel Day-Lewis. Also downright laughable was the Indians dying the hair of the main white captive and putting tanning cream on her skin to make her look more native AmericanDidn't show what brands the Indians used. There also seemed to be plenty of eye make-up around for when the white females grew up so they always looked gorgeous. Overall this is a very amateurish and trite, untrue-to-life tale. This is particularly disappointing since Christians having been making better "faith-based" films of late such as, 'God's Not Dead' and "War Room.' This is definitely a rental and not something I would want to own. I viewed it from a copy from the library.

Starting in 1775 we have a story of a German family who emigrated to America to avoid religious persecution. They buy their own land in an area that was previously the domain of the local Native Indian Tribe. The British are at war with the French  again  and both sides drag the local populace into the conflict and the local tribes also.

This results in a previously allied tribe raiding the frontier homesteads and killing, burning and taking prisoners. This includes Barbara Leininger and her sister. What follows is what befalls them and their friends.

Now I love a good frontier tale, the Native Americans are really done well and some of the locations are excellent  I think they used the same area as Michael Mann in The Last of the Mohicans so very evocative. The acting ranges from good to am dram and that is a shame. Some of the characters are stereo typed to the point of incredulity  especially a couple of the English officers. Then there are the wigs which started of being funny and then became annoying. I have seen more realistic toupees on sale in a joke shop. Why ruin a film that had a fair amount of money spent on it with minor hic cups? If you like a frontier story with a  bit of action and some great fancy dress then there may be a great film here for you, if you like true quality in your films then think twice.

An excellent movie, based upon the real-life story of sisters Barbara and Regina Leininger and their neighbor/friend Marie LaRoy.  Caught in the midst of the French and Indian War, several members of the Leininger Family, and most of the LaRoy Family were killed, with the young girls being hauled off as plunder to live as Indians in Ohio.  In a daring escape, (punishable by burning at the stake if caught) Barbara and Marie with two other captives traversed hundred of miles of hostile territory seeking freedom.  The story is a rare glimpse into the suffering and sacrifices of so many Scottish, German and English families living along the Pennsylvania and Virginia frontiers in 1755.  A must see movie that will encourage and inspire its viewers of the power of faith to bring one through even the most difficult circumstances.  An excellent movie, presenting an important piece of American History.  Highly recommend - a must see!
